messages.subject: RE: [unschoolingbasics] Re: RE: radical unschooling
messages.msgSnippet: Thank you for this list of books. I was able to find many of them on Amazon. I had a book fest yesterday! I bought several of them. Thanks again Pamela. Aubrey
messages.messageBody:
Thank you for this list of books. I was able to find many of them on Amazon. I had a book fest yesterday! I bought several of them.

Thanks again Pamela.

Aubrey



_____

From: unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com [mailto:unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Pamela Sorooshian
Sent: Monday, October 24, 2005 1:38 PM
To: unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [unschoolingbasics] Re: RE: radical unschooling



There are many better books out there:

Moving a Puddle, and other essays by Sandra Dodd <http://
sandradodd.com/puddlebook>
Essays on learning in a home without school, on living respectfully
with children and of creating a nest in which learning flourishes.

Parenting a Free Child by Rue Kream <http://www.freechild.info/>

The Unschooling Handbook : How to Use the Whole World As Your Child's
Classroom by Mary Griffith

Homeschooling Our Children Unschooling Ourselves by Alison McKee

The Unprocessed Child: Living Without School by Valerie Fitzenreiter

The Teenage Liberation Handbook: How to Quit School and Get a Real
Life and Education by Grace Llewellyn

Real Lives: Eleven Teenagers Who Don't Go to School Tell Their Own
Stories by Grace Llewellyn

Deschooling Our Lives by Matt Hern

Child's Work: Taking Children's Choices Seriously by Nancy Wallace

Better Than School: One Family's Declaration of Independence by Nancy
Wallace

I Learn Better by Teaching Myself and Still Teaching Ourselves: And,
Still Teaching Ourselves by Agnes Leistico

The Homeschooling Book of Answers : The 101 Most Important Questions
Answered by Homeschooling's Most Respected Voices (Prima Home
Learning Library) by Linda Dobson

The Art of Education by Linda Dobson

Homeschooling: A Patchwork of Days: Share a Day With 30 Homeschooling
Families by Nancy Lande

Fundamentals of Homeschooling: Notes on Successful Family Living by
Ann Lahrson-Fisher

Trust the Children: A Manual and Activity Guide for Homeschooling and
Alternative Learning by Anna Kealoha

Homeschooling for Excellence by David Colfax, Micki Colfax

Hard Times in Paradise: An American Family's Struggle to Carve Out a
Homestead in California's Redwood Mountains by David Colfax, Micki
Colfax

Have Fun. Learn Stuff. Grow. : Homeschooling and the Curriculum of
Love by David H. Albert

And the Skylark Sings with Me - Adventures in Homeschooling and
Community-Based Education by David H. Albert

Homeschooling and the Voyage of Self-Discovery by David H. Albert


PLUS the following books are by John Holt. I'd start with the most
recent ones - he changed his mind through the years as he gave up on
school reform and began to increasingly understand what children
living in freedom were truly capable of.

How Children Fail, 1964
How Children Learn, 1967
The Underachieving School, 1969
What Do I Do Monday? 1970
Freedom and Beyond, 1972
Escape from Childhood: The Needs and Rights of Children, 1975
Instead of Education: Ways to Help People Do Things Better, 1976
Never Too late: My Musical Life Story, 1978
Teach Your Own: A Hopeful Path for Education, 1981
Teach Your Own: The John Holt Book of Homeschooling, 2003 (This is
John Holt's 1981 book as revised and updated by Patrick Farenga.)


￼

￼

￼

messages.messageBody:

any of them will go write a little blurb to help others figure out
which ones they might want to read, that would be great!

Here is the link:

<http://www.unschooling.info/forum/>
Look under the category, "Beginning Unschooling" for the "Unschooling
Books."

-pam

Unschooling.info message boards and let people write short reviews.
Then we'll stick them on the unschooling.info website. Sound good?

-pam

messages.subject: Re: [unschoolingbasics] Re: RE: radical unschooling
messages.msgSnippet: There are many better books out there: Moving a Puddle, and other essays by Sandra Dodd  Essays on learning in a home
messages.messageBody:
There are many better books out there:

Moving a Puddle, and other essays by Sandra Dodd <http://
sandradodd.com/puddlebook>
Essays on learning in a home without school, on living respectfully
with children and of creating a nest in which learning flourishes.

Parenting a Free Child by Rue Kream <http://www.freechild.info/>

The Unschooling Handbook : How to Use the Whole World As Your Child's
Classroom by Mary Griffith

Homeschooling Our Children Unschooling Ourselves by Alison McKee

The Unprocessed Child: Living Without School by Valerie Fitzenreiter

The Teenage Liberation Handbook: How to Quit School and Get a Real
Life and Education by Grace Llewellyn

Real Lives: Eleven Teenagers Who Don't Go to School Tell Their Own
Stories by Grace Llewellyn

Deschooling Our Lives by Matt Hern

Child's Work: Taking Children's Choices Seriously by Nancy Wallace

Better Than School: One Family's Declaration of Independence by Nancy
Wallace

I Learn Better by Teaching Myself and Still Teaching Ourselves: And,
Still Teaching Ourselves by Agnes Leistico

The Homeschooling Book of Answers : The 101 Most Important Questions
Answered by Homeschooling's Most Respected Voices (Prima Home
Learning Library) by Linda Dobson

The Art of Education by Linda Dobson

Homeschooling: A Patchwork of Days: Share a Day With 30 Homeschooling
Families by Nancy Lande

Fundamentals of Homeschooling: Notes on Successful Family Living by
Ann Lahrson-Fisher

Trust the Children: A Manual and Activity Guide for Homeschooling and
Alternative Learning by Anna Kealoha

Homeschooling for Excellence by David Colfax, Micki Colfax

Hard Times in Paradise: An American Family's Struggle to Carve Out a
Homestead in California's Redwood Mountains by David Colfax, Micki
Colfax

Have Fun. Learn Stuff. Grow. : Homeschooling and the Curriculum of
Love by David H. Albert

And the Skylark Sings with Me - Adventures in Homeschooling and
Community-Based Education by David H. Albert

Homeschooling and the Voyage of Self-Discovery by David H. Albert


PLUS the following books are by John Holt. I'd start with the most
recent ones - he changed his mind through the years as he gave up on
school reform and began to increasingly understand what children
living in freedom were truly capable of.

How Children Fail, 1964
How Children Learn, 1967
The Underachieving School, 1969
What Do I Do Monday? 1970
Freedom and Beyond, 1972
Escape from Childhood: The Needs and Rights of Children, 1975
Instead of Education: Ways to Help People Do Things Better, 1976
Never Too late: My Musical Life Story, 1978
Teach Your Own: A Hopeful Path for Education, 1981
Teach Your Own: The John Holt Book of Homeschooling, 2003 (This is
John Holt's 1981 book as revised and updated by Patrick Farenga.)


￼

￼

￼

messages.subject: RE: [unschoolingbasics] Re: RE: radical unschooling
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks to everyone for answering my questions. There are still some things I m not quite getting but I just ordered Rue s book. I m sure it will help Has
messages.messageBody:
Thanks to everyone for answering my questions. There are still some things
I'm not quite "getting" but I just ordered Rue's book. I'm sure it will help

Has anyone ever heard of a book called Life Long Learning by Patti Diamond?
I was going to order that as well.

Thanks, Aubrey



_____

From: unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com
[mailto:unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of KathrynJB@...
Sent: Monday, October 24, 2005 8:11 AM
To: unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [unschoolingbasics] Re: RE: radical unschooling




I am a Holt fan, but I have to say that we now have cool books written by
and for real unschoolers, who have children of their own who can tell you
what
life is like day to day. Holt never had children, so ultimately he was an
observer. He also died a long time ago, now, and I think unschoolers today
are
in a much different place. Read Rue's book.
Kathryn
******************************************************

In a message dated 10/24/2005 9:04:08 AM Eastern Daylight Time,
unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com writes:

<<<<< **John Holt's books in the order they were published:
http://www.unschooling.info/johnholt.htm and a recommended book list:
http://www.unschooling.info/books.htm. ~Rue >>>>

Oh for crying out loud, here is RUE touting John Holt's books, and not
mentioning her own wonderful tome!

Rue's book focuses more on the Whole Life part than John Holt's (in my
reading of his books) which begin from the un*School* side.

Rue Kream, "Parenting a Free Child"

http://www.freechild.info/

messages.subject: radical unschooling
messages.msgSnippet: Aubrey, radical unschooling can be a lot to take, in one dose, when you are new at unschooling.  It was a gradual process for me and it took a while.  I know a
messages.messageBody:
Aubrey, radical unschooling can be a lot to take, in one dose, when
you are new at unschooling. It was a gradual process for me and it
took a while. I know a book that was a good starting point for me
was Living Joyfully With Children. I would consider it the first
step towards being radical, as far as the philosophy spilling over
into other areas of my life. It was the book that helped me shift
my thinking a little, give it a try! I also recommend just reading,
reading, reading, not just on the lists but any book on unschooling
that you can get your hands on. I got onto half.com, using the
recommended list on unschooling.com, which doesn't exist anymore.
You can get books for REALLY cheap there, most of mine I didn't pay
more than about $7 for. Kelly, do you know where another
recommended book list is? Maybe on unschooling.info? Some that I
enjoyed were The Art of Education, The Unschooling Handbook, Dumbing
Us Down, any of John Holts books. Maybe Kelly or some others would
have some book suggestions on ones that touched on the whole life
instead of just the school issue. And if you didn't make it to the
conference then maybe you could order tapes of the talks that took
place at the conference, they touch on just about everything. Hope
that helps.

Heidi
Mom to Kevin (13), Tristan (10), and Calista (6)
Children aren't coloring books. You can't fill them with your
favorite colors. From The Kite Runner
